creator: coad@measurement-factory.com
text:
Looks like a possible RFC 2616 MUST violation. 
Apache ingores(?) Connection header tokens when
many headers/tokens are present. Apache must remove
matching headers instead.

See attached trace for details and ways to reproduce.

Test case IDs in the trace link to human-oriented test case
description and RFC quotes, if available.
*** Bug 16122 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: coad@measurement-factory.com

text:
In this test case, was the connection header broken up over multiple lines?

This would suggest that it was:

Connection: X-hcfzqxtmkxt,X-rdbooiitzbh,X-omucmqyqvpl\r\n

Where any of the headers removed? Looking at the code, it "should work", I am
just trying to figure out whether the multiple line possiblity may be involved.
creator: minfrin@sharp.fm

text:
There are several Connection headers, one line each (not sure what you mean
by multiple lines).

Yes, several headers were correctly removed. Here is a uote from the
attached trace:

263.744| found correctly removed response header field: X-tjwreuddipm
263.744| found correctly removed response header field: X-fseplnrrqks

Those are the headers mentioned in the first Connection header.

The log shows you everything except for a boring repetition of Connection
and extension headers in the middle of the response header. The latter
does not cross header boundaries (i.e., only complete headers can be
hidden that way).
creator: coad@measurement-factory.com

text:
Which of them were not removed when they should have been? Was there one that
was present, two, more than two? I am just trying to figure out if this is an
edge case of some kind, where either the first, the last, or both the headers in
the list are not removed.
creator: minfrin@sharp.fm

text:
It is all in the attached trace :-).

Headers correctly removed:
        found correctly removed response header field: X-tjwreuddipm
        found correctly removed response header field: X-fseplnrrqks

Headers incorrectly forwarded:
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-jnublzanxmw
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-hcfzqxtmkxt
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-rdbooiitzbh
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-omucmqyqvpl
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-fgpwbbbjhxg
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-gpmuwciakhj
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-avhrlxqthlj
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-mixddigrvbf
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-jirccalmewg
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-dbnnrteewmz
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-kgnqjduacbx
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-qnwbttimpwq
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-vvvpiwvssdu
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-xvelcxvxgrn
        found incorrectly forwarded response header field: X-npdovskhump

I am not sure what you mean by "one that was present". All of the above were
present in the original response, probably had unique field names, and were
mentioned in the original Connection: header value.

I am guessing that the proxy honored the first Connection: header only
(mentioning X-tjwreuddipm and X-fseplnrrqks) and ignored all other
Connection: headers.

Does this clarify?
creator: coad@measurement-factory.com

text: Please check with later versions and reopen if needed.
creator: jim@apache.org
